dt: {bc}lacking in qualities that interest, {d_link|stimulate|stimulate}, or challenge {bc}{sx|dull||}, {sx|flat||}

pt: {sc}insipid{/sc} {sc}vapid{/sc} {sc}flat{/sc} {sc}jejune{/sc} {sc}banal{/sc} {sc}inane{/sc} mean devoid of qualities that make for spirit and character. {sc}insipid{/sc} implies a lack of sufficient taste or savor to please or interest.

pt.t: an {it}insipid{/it} romance with platitudes on every page

pt: {sc}vapid{/sc} suggests a lack of liveliness, force, or spirit.

pt.t: an exciting story given a {it}vapid{/it} treatment

pt: {sc}flat{/sc} applies to things that have lost their sparkle or zest.

pt.t: although well-regarded in its day, the novel now seems {it}flat{/it}

pt: {sc}jejune{/sc} suggests a lack of rewarding or satisfying substance.
{sc}banal{/sc} stresses the complete absence of freshness, novelty, or immediacy.
{sc}inane{/sc} implies a lack of any significant or convincing quality.

quotes.t: While it is fashionable to write off that decade as an {qword}insipid{/qword} time, one long pajama party, the '50s, in sport at least, were a revolutionary age.
I'd climbed and fished in the emptiest reaches of the American West, but Alaska made the wilds of the lower 48 seem {qword}insipid{/qword} and tame, a toothless simulacrum.
One evening, over beers, Rasala complained about some {qword}insipid{/qword} movie recently shown on TV.
By contrast, what we know as "popular" or "mass" culture has always conformed to the most {qword}insipid{/qword} prejudices, and the least subtle formulations, of society.

et: French & Late Latin; French {it}insipide{/it}, from Late Latin {it}insipidus{/it}, from Latin {it}in-{/it} + {it}sapidus{/it} savory, from {it}sapere{/it} to taste {ma}{mat|sage|}{/ma}
shortdef: lacking in qualities that interest, stimulate, or challenge : dull, flat
